title: 108_hr2539
content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Congress finds that individuals under 18 account for a significant portion of crime victims, especially in sex crimes and kidnappings. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more than twice as likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, leading to serious consequences such as 1,200 child deaths from abuse annually and nearly 879,000 child abuse victims. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families, including delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased likelihood of experiencing or perpetrating domestic violence as an adult. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families adequately. Failure to pay child support is a form of child abuse. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families, leading to neglect. Failure to pay child support contributes to neglect as it increases the likelihood of children living in poverty and facing challenges in education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It states that anyone who willfully injures a person under 18 years of age by force or threat of force can face imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. If death results from the offense, the perpetrator can be imprisoned for any term of years or for life. The new section on violence against children in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, imposes imprisonment and fines for injuring a person under 18 years of age. If death results from the offense, the perpetrator can face imprisonment for any term of years or for life. The circumstances for imposing imprisonment and fines for violence against children involve conduct across state lines or using interstate commerce, or employing certain weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce. The section outlines penalties for offenses involving violence against children across state lines or using interstate commerce, or employing certain weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce. The section addresses enhanced penalties for crimes against children under federal law and mandates a review of state laws regarding penalties for crimes against children. The Comptroller General of the United States will review state laws on penalties for crimes against children, including sentencing practices and enhanced penalties for child victims, and report findings to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 102. Enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors if requested by a State, Indian tribal government, or local government. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors, prioritizing cases involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states or rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in the effective law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children by providing personnel, training, technical assistance, data collection, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. Training is provided for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel to better identify and respond to crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants for the effective law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, including training for personnel to identify and respond to these crimes. Grants are used for training law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel, developing units targeting crimes against children, and implementing effective policies and services for preventing and responding to these crimes. The Attorney General awards grants for law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, focusing on developing effective policies, protocols, and data systems to prevent, identify, and respond to these crimes. Additionally, programs promoting cross-collaboration are encouraged and strengthened. The legislation focuses on tracking arrests, prosecutions, and convictions for crimes against children, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with such crimes. The legislation aims to address crimes against children by developing programs for Indian tribes and requiring applications for grants to be submitted to the Attorney General. The legislation requires applicants for grants to describe the purposes, use, and expected results of the grant funds. Applicants must also demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant. The legislation requires grant applicants to describe the purposes, use, and expected results of the funds. They must also show consultation with victim services programs and certify that federal funds will supplement existing resources. The legislation requires grant applicants to describe the purposes, use, and expected results of the funds. They must also certify that federal funds will supplement existing resources and ensure compliance with specific sections. The legislation authorizes $25,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2008 for compliance with specific sections by the State or local government. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in providing education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for educational seminars, hotlines, and training programs for professionals. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, and emergency medical treatment. The grants awarded by the Attorney General aim to prevent crimes against children, provide emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increase mental health professionals specializing in helping victims. Each eligible entity must submit an application to receive a grant. Each eligible entity must submit an application to the Attorney General to receive a grant for preventing crimes against children, providing emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in helping victims. The application must meet the requirements specified by the Attorney General. Applicants for grants under this section must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds. They must also demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant. Applicants must describe the expected results from grant funds and demonstrate consultation with victim services programs for crimes against children when developing a plan to implement the grant. Applicants must work with nonprofit victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes, and certify their experience in providing education, prevention, or intervention services related to crimes against children. Applicants must have experience in providing services to victims of crimes against children and certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for activities funded under this section. The Attorney General may waive the requirement for nongovernmental organizations in extraordinary circumstances, and the state or tribal government must be in compliance with the activities funded under this section. The local government or State where the nongovernmental organization operates must comply with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for this section annually from 2004 to 2008. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must have a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use the National Incident-Based Reporting System for statistical gathering.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under this Act must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history with parent approval, and involve law enforcement after child relinquishment. The State must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously, collect family medical history with parent approval, involve law enforcement after child relinquishment, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law. The State's Safe Haven law includes a plan for publicizing it. An exception allows a State statute to deny a parent the ability to leave a newborn anonymously if signs of abuse or intentional harm are present. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. Each State receiving child welfare funding must submit a report on their program within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices and policies in child welfare programs. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies in child welfare programs, including how States are maintaining records and verifying the well-being of children under their care. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies in child welfare programs, including record-keeping, child well-being verification, review system impact, best practices, and legislative recommendations. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for tax purposes.
